setup.question: How did Quade feel about the situation?
answers: He wished he was getting hazard pay
He was less cautious than others

Text.text: Quade feels negatively about the situation because he wishes he was getting hazard pay. This is literally proven by the context of the story:
. Here, Quade is reacting to getting demoted from his current rank to "

, which leads him to lose his hazard pay, delaying his retirement process. It's important to recognize that while Quade may have wished he was more cautious, this is only because of the consequences of his actions having costed his hazard pay, which is the driving motivation for his feelings. Not to mention the word "cautious" is never used in regards to Quade in this story.

Captain Gavin, the narrator, and his crew are on a space mission where their video screens are glitching.Thus, the situation is unknown, yet Quade insists that it's transphasia while Gavin is more cautious.
Gavin and Quade argue, with Quade still stubbornly insisting he's right, to the point where Gavin says
It is not A, bc hazard pay is just a throwaway line that Quade uses as a retort to the Captain.
Hazard pay is not a "throwaway" line, as Debater B suggests. It is used in two very separate incidents.

This justification is that Quade is confident in his evaluation of the situation BECAUSE of his rank and the hazard pay that comes with it. His caution, is derived from his self-confidence in his rank, which means his rank fuels his thinking. In this hierarchy, one's pay is equivalent to one's seniority, and Quade clearly enjoys having his seniority. LASTLY, debater B doesn't even use a quote from Quade about his cautiousness!

Judge, the ev A uses literally shows Quade talking back to his superior, showcasing how overconfident and thus less cautious Quade is. Hazard pay is only used by Quade to justify his overconfidence or try to get out of going on a mission with the Captain that he hates. However, we see many examples of Quade's lack of caution: when an unknown pain affects him and the Captain, instead of stopping, he tries to follow:
Even when Quade knows nothing about the environment, he boasts of his abilies:
again showing his lack of caution.

If you look at any of Debater B's evidence, you will find a shocking pattern: none of their evidence has anything to do with Quade's FEELINGS. Proving Quade isn't cautious IS NOT the point of this debate. It is what he feels. Quade's recognition of his cautiousness is blatantly not there. BUT, he is repeatedly discussing his hazard pay. Because that is what actually MATTERS to him.

, Here we see that hazard pay dictates his seniority, because he doesn't believe he has to help the rookies. Quade's incompetence is a reoccurring issue because he only cares about things like money and status.

1. Quade is actually not incompetent, he is FEELING overconfident and thus less cautious, which I have proved in ev above and will have more ev later, unlike A where hazard pay is literally mentioned 2x. 
2. Quade's overconfidence:
3. Quade's value/his compentence.
-> A is caught in a blatant lie.

This debate was over before it began. Mostly because the point I made last speech was straight fire - Quade isn't aware of his own less cautiousness. The question of this debate literally resides A because the B answer doesn't answer the question. Quade doesn't feel less cautious, he is less cautious. That is a matter of action, not a matter of feeling. BUT, he very clearly feels bad about his hazard pay. All of my prior evidence stands. I'll answer their horrible line by line now:
1. He is confident, and by proxy overconfident to the other crewmates but at no point does he recogonize his lack of caution.
2. Once again he's just overconfident, not aware of the fact he's less cautious.
3. What blatant lie? This is non-responsive.

A has continually tried to make this debate about semantics when I have been consistently providing facts and ev. Judge you should be highly suspicious about their last ditch attempt that was their last speech, especially how they could not refute any of my points. Also, Quade does come to the realization that he was less cautious at the end of the story:

Both sides build Quade up as overconfident and money focused. I end up voting B because I'm getting way more in terms of proving Quade's overconfidence and lack of caution than him wishing he received hazard pay from the situation. As I understand it, the situation is the space mission, not the demotion, which I should be focusing on, and the first quote from A comes super late in the story, so I'm inclined to believe he was getting hazard pay before. The honest debater needs to clarify the story way more though, I have hardly any clue what's going on outside of these two choices.

This question is phrased weirdly since as was pointed out by A, it asks how Quade FEELS about the situation, and B. he WAS less cautious is not quite a feeling. This is why I'd be inclined to go with answer A, but not by a long margin as it does seem his losing hazard pay was a result of the lack of caution, and really the debate could go either way since it's apparent Quad was, in fact, less cautious than others. Neither side, in my opinion, proved their point over another--mostly, I'm just going with my gut.

answers.reason for outcome: Quality of evidence, although argumentation nearly won the dishonest debater the round

I got the wrong answer because I was confused about the phrasing of the questions and answer. As the dishonest debater A pointed out, Quade could not really "feel" that he was being less cautious than other--perhaps he could've wished that he was less cautious, but it didn't seem to me that that was right. Particularly because it seemed to me that both answers were actually simultaneously true, I chose the side that made the most sense in the context of the question, sort of disregarding the subject of the debate itself, which was probably misguided in retrospect.
